awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Units of orthographic complexity and their influence in speech production
awd_abstract_narration:
How does literacy impact speech? There is evidence that the number of symbols in the written form of a sound can influence how long that sound is produced, even when a written form is not explicitly present. For example, the final /k/ sounds in the English words "tic", "click", and "clique" are represented by 1, 2, and 3 letters, respectively. When people produce these words, the final /k/ of "click" is produced longer than than the final /k/ of "tic". And the final /k/ of "clique" is produced longer still. Therefore, it has been hypothesized that as the complexity of a written form increases, so too does the speech duration of the associated sound, all else being equal. This phenomenon is inconsistent with some models of language production which argue that written information should not influence speech, especially when written information is not explicitly present. Additionally, it remains unclear exactly which types of written information can influence speech duration as there is disagreement about the mechanisms that drive this effect. Some argue the relationship between sounds and written symbols underlie this effect. Others argue the amount of visual information itself regardless of any connection to sounds is driving these duration differences. This study examines the relationship between sounds, symbols, and speech duration to develop our understanding of what types of written information can alter speech patterns. Addressing this question will inform theoretical models of human speech production. Additionally, data collected through this research can be incorporated into computational speech synthesis and speech recognition systems for more accurate, robust, and natural models of human speech. 

A challenge of previous research in this area was that it relied upon natural speech data which includes many external factors across individuals that can influence speech duration outside of written forms (e.g. word frequency). To gain greater control of these variables, the current study will employ a three-day novel-word-learning experiment in which participants learn sets of novel non-word homophones along with one of several novel writing systems. Novel homophones in a set are learned as the same word phonologically but are written distinctly. Written complexity for homophones may vary by: a) number of whole characters; b) number of pen strokes; c) number of components with phonological associations; d) number of components without phonological associations. Participants will produce learned words in a picture-naming task without written forms explicitly present. Participants' production will be recorded and speech duration will be measured. Duration among homophones in a set and across writing systems will be compared to determine: a) if increased written complexity influences duration even when written forms are not explicitly present; b) which types of written information may influence duration and whether written complexity must have a phonological association to influence speech; and c) at which point in the training process speech patterns change and whether these patterns persist through the end of the experimental period. This data will comprise a portion of the doctoral dissertation. An earlier portion of the dissertation investigated similar durational phenomenon in Japanese speakers in regards to written character complexity. To remain consistent with previous data set, retain the ability to compare results from the current study with earlier data in the dissertation, and provide the opportunity to replicate previous findings in the current study, participants for the current study will be native Japanese speakers.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to investigate the impact of written language on spoken language. Previous research found that as the number of alphabetic letters or logographic characters in a written form increases, so too can speech duration. However, it was unclear whether other forms of visual/graphic complexity can influence speech in similar ways and whether there are specific qualities or requirements that written word complexity must meet. Some theories argue that the phonological associations of written symbols drive changes in speech behavior. These theories predict that measures of written complexity without phonological correspondences (e.g. individual pen strokes of a letter) should not affect speech duration. In addition, some speech production models argue that in cases where written language is not explicitly present, spoken language cannot be affected by written language. According to these theories, speech patterns in these cases are a consequence of recency effects or training effects and not a direct result of written language fundamentally altering speech.

This project employed a series of three-day novel word learning experiments that taught participants sets of heterographic homophones (words that are pronounced the same but spelled differently) to further investigate: 1) the effects from categories of written word complexity on speech duration (a: number of pen strokes individually; b: number of whole characters individually; c: number of pen strokes & whole characters combined; d: number of character-internal components with explicit phonological associations; e: number of character-internal components without explicit phonological associations); 2) the timeframe for which speech duration effects may appear (the day novel written forms are introduced; persisting into the day following the introduction of novel written forms); and 3) the types of tasks in which changes in speech duration may be present (reading tasks in which written forms were explicitly present; picture naming tasks in which written forms were not explicitly present). An earlier portion of the Co-PI?s dissertation research investigated effects from written word complexity from Japanese words with native Japanese speakers. To retain the ability to compare results with this previous study, the Co-PI traveled to Kobe City University of Foreign Studies in Japan, hosted by Dr. Montserrat Sanz, to conduct these experiments with a similar population of native Japanese speakers.

The results of these experiments showed that speech duration significantly increased as written word complexity increased for words that varied by pen strokes & whole characters combined and for words that varied by character-internal components without explicit phonological associations. For both of these cases, significant speech duration effects were observed in the final session of the experiment in which participants received no additional training for novel written words. However, speech duration effects were limited to reading tasks. No significant speech duration effects were observed in picture naming tasks nor for words that varied by pen strokes individually, whole characters individually, or character-internal components with explicit phonological associations.

Results from the current project support the hypothesis that written language can play a fundamental role in speech production. The impact from written forms on speech is both broader and more restricted than previously understood. The current project finds that character-internal forms of written word complexity, like components, can influence speech duration, as well. Results from previous research had been limited to speech duration effects correlated with whole units like letters or characters. In addition, characters may interact with speech distinctly from letters. The current study found no influence on speech duration from characters in tasks when written word information was not explicitly present (i.e. picture naming tasks). This is contrasted with results from previous studies that have found durational effects associated with letters in tasks when written forms were not explicitly present.

Hypotheses for how written word forms affect speech may require modification. The results of this project suggest that categories of written word complexity may influence speech distinctly. Phonological correspondences may be a necessary for written forms to influence speech duration but perhaps only for written units with phonological correspondences around the individual phone level, like letters. Characters, which have broader phonological correspondences around the syllable level or morpheme level, may affect speech duration through a separate route by which phonological correspondences are not a necessity. However, this route may require written units be explicitly present for speech to be impacted. The current project highlights the complex relationship between written word complexity and speech and lays a strong foundation for future research.

This project resulted in the completion of the Co-PI?s dissertation: The ink in our speech: Influence from orthographic complexity in speech production (Grippando, 2020). Results from this project may have applications in further developing speech recognition and synthesis systems through integration of durational speech patterns assosciated with written word complexity. Similar applications may have the potential to assist in identifying learning disabilities through automated analysis of speech patterns.
